channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Forget tedious paper applications, Americans can now renew passports online
item.description: The State Department announced Wednesday that its online renewal system is now fully operational, after testing in pilot programs, and available to adult passport holders whose passport had expired within the past five years or will expire in the coming year.
item.content:encoded:
The State Department announced Wednesday that its online renewal system is now fully operational, after testing in pilot programs, and available to adult passport holders whose passport had expired within the past five years or will expire in the coming year.

(Image credit: Jenny Kane/AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Vance says Haitian migrants with protected status are 'illegal aliens' to be deported
item.description: The Republican vice presidential nominee continues to rail against Haitian migrants living in Ohio, though many have Temporary Protected Status, as the GOP escalates its hardline immigration stance.
item.content:encoded:
The Republican vice presidential nominee continues to rail against Haitian migrants living in Ohio, though many have Temporary Protected Status, as the GOP escalates its hardline immigration stance.

(Image credit: Karl B DeBlaker)
item.dc:creator: Stephen Fowler

item.title: Here are 4 ways the Federal Reserve's big rate cut could change the housing market
item.description: Here's a look at what the Federal Reserve's rate cut will mean for those looking to buy — or sell — a home.
item.content:encoded:
Here's a look at what the Federal Reserve's rate cut will mean for those looking to buy — or sell — a home.

(Image credit: Patrick T. Fallon)
item.dc:creator: Laurel Wamsley

item.title: Harvey Weinstein pleads not guilty to new sex crime charge in New York
item.description: Prosecutors revealed last week that Weinstein had been indicted on additional sex crime charges that weren’t part of the case that led to his now-overturned 2020 conviction.
item.content:encoded:
Prosecutors revealed last week that Weinstein had been indicted on additional sex crime charges that weren’t part of the case that led to his now-overturned 2020 conviction.

(Image credit: Seth Wenig)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: In Kashmir, voting begins in first local elections since India revoked autonomy
item.description: In Indian-controlled Kashmir, residents are voting in elections that some hope will lead to restoration of the territory's statehood, which ended when it became a federally governed territory in 2019.
item.content:encoded:
In Indian-controlled Kashmir, residents are voting in elections that some hope will lead to restoration of the territory's statehood, which ended when it became a federally governed territory in 2019.

(Image credit: Channi Anand)
item.dc:creator: Omkar Khandekar

item.title: In break with tradition, the Teamsters will not endorse a presidential candidate
item.description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, a union of 1.3 million workers, will not endorse Vice President Harris or former President Donald Trump for president, after decades of backing Democrats.
item.content:encoded:
The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, a union of 1.3 million workers, will not endorse Vice President Harris or former President Donald Trump for president, after decades of backing Democrats.

(Image credit: Patrick T. Fallon)
item.dc:creator: Don Gonyea

item.title: What is School Like for Children in War Zones?
item.description:
Life is uncertain for children in war zones. There, school can be a source of stability or just another thing that war obliterates. We hear reports on what school is like in three of the world's most active war zones: Sudan, Gaza and Ukraine.

Sign up for State of the World+ to listen sponsor-free and support the work of NPR journalists. Visit plus.npr.org.
item.content:encoded:
Life is uncertain for children in war zones. There, school can be a source of stability or just another thing that war obliterates. We hear reports on what school is like in three of the world's most active war zones: Sudan, Gaza and Ukraine.

Sign up for State of the World+ to listen sponsor-free and support the work of NPR journalists. Visit plus.npr.org.

(Image credit: Joanna Kakissis)
item.dc:creator: Joanna Kakissis

item.title: JD Souther, who collaborated on 'Heartache Tonight' and other Eagles hits, dies at 78
item.description: Souther was a prolific songwriter and musician who helped shape the country-rock sound that took root in Southern California in the 1970s with his collaborations with the Eagles and Linda Ronstadt.
item.content:encoded:
Souther was a prolific songwriter and musician who helped shape the country-rock sound that took root in Southern California in the 1970s with his collaborations with the Eagles and Linda Ronstadt.

(Image credit: Charles Sykes)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Another wave of blasts hits Lebanon, as Hezbollah reels from pager explosions
item.description: Following Tuesday's stunning attack via pagers, Lebanon was hit by another deadly wave of exploding communications devices on Wednesday.
item.content:encoded:
Following Tuesday's stunning attack via pagers, Lebanon was hit by another deadly wave of exploding communications devices on Wednesday.

(Image credit: Bilal Hussein)
item.dc:creator: Jawad Rizkallah

item.title: The Federal Reserve starts cutting interest rates in a big moment for the economy
item.description: The Federal Reserve moved aggressively Wednesday to start cutting interest rates as easing inflation fears gives way to concern about the job market.
item.content:encoded:
The Federal Reserve moved aggressively Wednesday to start cutting interest rates as easing inflation fears gives way to concern about the job market.

(Image credit: Win McNamee)
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley
